importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the Hamas-led attack on Israel that triggered the current conflict and led to the military campaign in Gaza.
The date the ceasefire with Hamas came into effect, marking a turning point in the humanitarian crisis in Gaza.
The date the article was published, indicating the current state of the crisis and ongoing international response.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from the Hamas attack on 7 October 2023 to the present reflects the duration of the conflict, destruction, and ongoing humanitarian crisis in Gaza.

keyTakeAways: The health situation in Gaza is described as a 'catastrophe' that will last for generations due to famine, destroyed healthcare infrastructure, and widespread mental health issues.
Aid deliveries into Gaza remain critically insufficient, with only 200–300 aid lorries per day instead of the required 600, and supplies being confiscated or restricted.
Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, WHO Director-General, warns that humanitarian aid must be delivered without conditions, especially after the release of Israeli hostages and transfer of remains.
Israel has restricted or halted aid deliveries on multiple occasions, citing security concerns, including dual-use of medical supplies.
The UN estimates $70 billion is needed to reconstruct Gaza, with about 10% allocated to rebuilding the health system.
Thousands of Palestinians are waiting for medical evacuation flights, which have not taken off for two weeks due to religious holidays, resulting in deaths.
The US brokered the ceasefire and has a responsibility to ensure its enforcement, including unrestricted aid access.
The ceasefire is fragile, with repeated violations leading to deaths even after peace was declared.

namedEntities.name: Gaza
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian territory in the Middle East, currently experiencing a severe humanitarian and health crisis.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The central location of the health crisis, destruction, and aid delivery issues described in the article.

namedEntities.name: World Health Organization (WHO)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A United Nations agency responsible for international public health and emergency response.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WHO chief, Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, provides the main expert assessment of the health crisis in Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Director-General of the World Health Organization, who delivered key warnings about the long-term health crisis in Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the primary voice in the article warning of a generational health catastrophe and calling for unrestricted aid access.

namedEntities.name: Israel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The state in the Middle East that launched military operations in Gaza following the Hamas attack in October 2023.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Israel controls aid access into Gaza and has restricted or halted deliveries, which is central to the humanitarian crisis described.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian militant group that has been involved in hostilities with Israel and controls parts of Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is involved in the conflict, including ceasefire negotiations, hostage exchanges, and claims regarding the return of dead bodies.

namedEntities.name: United States (US)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A global power that brokered the ceasefire and is involved in peace efforts in the region.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The US is seen as responsible for enforcing the ceasefire and ensuring unrestricted humanitarian aid.

namedEntities.name: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A UN body that coordinates humanitarian responses in crisis zones.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: OCHA's representative, Tom Fletcher, highlights the scale of the starvation crisis and the need for more aid.

namedEntities.name: World Food Programme (WFP)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A UN agency that distributes food aid to people in crisis.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP reports that food deliveries into Gaza have been insufficient despite the ceasefire.

namedEntities.name: Kerem Shalom
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A border crossing in southern Gaza operated by Israel.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: One of the two current crossings through which aid enters Gaza, but still insufficient to meet needs.

namedEntities.name: Kissufim
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A border crossing in central Gaza operated by Israel.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The second crossing through which aid enters Gaza, currently in use but not sufficient for full-scale aid delivery.

namedEntities.name: 7 October 2023
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The date of the Hamas-led attack on Israel that initiated the current military conflict.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This event marks the beginning of the conflict and the ongoing humanitarian crisis in Gaza.

namedEntities.name: 28 dead Israeli hostages
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The number of Israeli hostages taken during the Hamas attack on 7 October 2023.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The situation regarding the return of their remains is a key point of contention in the ceasefire negotiations.

namedEntities.name: 15 bodies returned by Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The number of Israeli hostage remains transferred by Hamas as of the article's publication.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Demonstrates ongoing issues with the return of remains and the failure to meet expectations for full closure of the hostage issue.

namedEntities.name: 6,700 tonnes of food
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The amount of food delivered to Gaza since 10 October 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Illustrates that current deliveries are still far below the 2,000-tonnes-per-day target needed to end the famine.

namedEntities.name: $70 billion
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The estimated cost to fully reconstruct Gaza, including health infrastructure.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Highlights the massive financial and logistical challenge of rebuilding after the conflict.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The percentage of the $70 billion reconstruction cost that must be allocated to healthcare.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Emphasizes the scale of the health system collapse and the need for urgent investment in medical recovery.

namedEntities.name: 700 people
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The number of Palestinians who have died while waiting for medical evacuation flights.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Demonstrates the deadly consequences of delayed medical evacuation due to religious holidays and insufficient flight schedules.

namedEntities.name: 2,000 tonnes per day
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The daily food aid target set by the UN to end the famine in Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The current delivery rate falls far short of this target, indicating a severe humanitarian shortfall.

namedEntities.name: 600 aid lorries per day
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The number of aid lorries needed daily to deliver sufficient supplies to Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The current average of 200–300 lorries per day is below this, showing a major delivery shortfall.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Health Organization's director-general, Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, has warned that the health crisis in Gaza constitutes a 'catastrophe' that will persist for generations due to famine, destroyed healthcare infrastructure, and widespread mental health issues. Despite a ceasefire with Hamas that began on 10 October 2025, aid deliveries remain critically insufficient—only 200 to 300 lorries per day instead of the required 600—with supplies often confiscated or restricted by Israeli authorities. Dr. Tedros emphasizes that aid must be delivered without conditions, especially after the release of Israeli hostages and the partial return of remains, and calls for all available crossings—including Kerem Shalom and Kissufim—to be fully opened. The UN estimates $70 billion is needed to rebuild Gaza, with 10% dedicated to health infrastructure. Thousands of Palestinians have died waiting for medical evacuation flights, highlighting the urgent need for increased access and action. The US, as the broker of the ceasefire, is expected to enforce it and ensure unrestricted humanitarian access, while Israel continues to face pressure to allow aid groups previously denied registration to operate.
title: Gaza health crisis will last for 'generations', WHO chief warns
